diseases.name: Malaria
diseases.about: Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by parasitic protozoans.
diseases.symptoms: Fever, chills, sweating, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, headache
diseases.prevention: Use of insecticide-treated nets, antimalarial drugs.
diseases.treatment: Antimalarial medications like chloroquine, artemisinin-based combination therapies
diseases.riskFactors: Living in or visiting malaria-endemic areas, not using mosquito nets.

diseases.name: Tuberculosis
diseases.about: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs.
diseases.symptoms: Cough with sputum, Chest pain, Weight loss, Night sweats
diseases.prevention: BCG vaccine, Good ventilation, Early treatment of active cases
diseases.treatment: Antimalarial medications like chloroquine, Artemisinin-based combination therapies
diseases.riskFactors: HIV infection, Substance use (such as injection drug use), Specialized treatment for rheumatoid arthritis or Crohn's disease, Organ transplants, Severe kidney disease, Diabetes

diseases.name: COVID-19
diseases.about: COVID-19 is a respiratory illness caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
diseases.symptoms: Fever, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, loss of taste or smell.
diseases.prevention: Vaccination, wearing masks, social distancing, hand hygiene.
diseases.treatment: Supportive care, antivirals (e.g., Remdesivir), oxygen therapy.
diseases.riskFactors: Older age, underlying health conditions, weakened immune system.

diseases.name: Dengue Fever
diseases.about: Dengue fever is a viral illness transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, causing flu-like symptoms.
diseases.symptoms: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, nausea, vomiting.
diseases.prevention: Avoiding mosquito bites, using insect repellents, wearing protective clothing, and eliminating mosquito breeding sites.
diseases.treatment: Supportive care, hydration, pain relievers (avoid aspirin), and in severe cases, hospitalization.
diseases.riskFactors: Living in or traveling to areas with mosquitoes, previous dengue infection.

diseases.name: Cholera
diseases.about: Cholera is an acute diarrheal disease caused by ingesting water or food contaminated with Vibrio cholerae bacteria.
diseases.symptoms: Severe watery diarrhea, vomiting, dehydration, muscle cramps.
diseases.prevention: Access to clean water, proper sanitation, good hygiene practices, and oral cholera vaccines.
diseases.riskFactors: Poor sanitation, lack of access to clean drinking water, inadequate handwashing.

diseases.name: HIV/AIDS
diseases.about: HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) attacks the immune system, potentially leading to AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome) if left untreated.
diseases.symptoms: Initial flu-like symptoms, weight loss, night sweats, swollen lymph nodes, recurrent infections.
diseases.prevention: Use of condoms, HIV testing, antiretroviral therapy (ART), needle exchange programs.
diseases.treatment: Antiretroviral therapy (ART), which can help control the virus and prevent progression to AIDS.
diseases.riskFactors: Unprotected sex, sharing needles, having multiple sexual partners, untreated sexually transmitted infections.

areas.name: Asia
areas.description: Asia is the largest continent, home to a variety of climates, from arid deserts to tropical forests. Its large population and varying healthcare infrastructure mean that both urban and rural areas are impacted by a range of diseases.

areas.name: Europe
areas.description: Europe is home to developed healthcare systems, but it still faces challenges such as the spread of diseases in densely populated urban areas and through travel and migration.

areas.name: North America
areas.description: North America has relatively high standards of healthcare, but communicable diseases can still spread, especially with travel and large urban centers.

areas.name: South America
areas.description: South America has diverse ecosystems, ranging from the Amazon Rainforest to mountainous regions. Disease transmission is often affected by environmental factors and lack of access to healthcare in rural areas.

areas.name: Antarctica
areas.description: Known for its cold and barren environment, Antarctica does not have permanent human settlements, but temporary research stations could see cases of infectious diseases in rare instances.

areas.name: Oceania
areas.description: The smallest continent, also known as Australia, is home to developed healthcare systems, but surrounding island nations in Oceania face unique challenges, including the spread of tropical diseases.

areas.name: South East Asia
areas.description: Communicable diseases like AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria and neglected tropical diseases have been the scourge of millions in South-East Asia, home to a quarter of the world's population.
